Observation/Comments: Fire hydrant and FDC locations are shown but required clear dimensioned distances to building, drive aisles, and obstructions are not provided; ability for fire department apparatus to access and connect is unclear.

Note “FOR HYDRAULIC REFERENCE ONLY (UG BY OTHERS)” leaves responsibility for underground fire service, valve arrangement, and backflow locations ambiguous; coordination of ownership and design scope between FP and civil/plumbing is unclear.

Fire pump test header and related piping are indicated but separation from public ways, vehicle impact protection, and drainage for test flows are not detailed; constructability and code compliance of test header location are unclear.
Riser room/fire pump room location and access path from exterior (including door identification and rated separation from other occupancies) are not clearly defined on the site plan.
Flow test data is shown but the test location relative to project connection point is not clearly identified on the plan, making hydraulic applicability to the building connection uncertain.

General notes reference NFPA standards but do not clearly state design density/area criteria and hazard classifications for building occupancies; sprinkler system basis of design is ambiguous at this stage.

No indication of required fire department access around the building perimeter (fire lanes, turning radii, overhead clearances) is provided; coordination with fire department access requirements is unclear.

Potential flood exposure from adjacent river is shown in vicinity graphics, but no indication that hydrants, FDC, or fire pump suction are elevated or protected against flood conditions; compliance with flood-resilience requirements is unclear.

Architectural cover sheet does not list fire-protection-related code information (occupancy classifications, construction type, sprinkler/standpipe requirements); FP design basis and coordination starting point are unclear.

Plumbing notes and site plan show domestic water and utilities but do not clearly depict the fire service main, backflow, or division of responsibility with FP underground; risk of conflict and missing scope for fire water service.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 210500 - Common work results for fire protection.pdf
Observation/Comments: Text states “Building or area will be fully sprinklered (exception only as per local code)” without defining any non-sprinklered spaces or referencing occupancy-specific exceptions; request explicit list of areas, if any, not to receive sprinklers for coordination.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 210500 - Common work results for fire protection.pdf
Observation/Comments: Specification references “combination standpipe and sprinkler riser system” but provides no performance criteria (class, zone limits, design pressures); request additional standpipe design parameters for layout and riser sizing.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 210500 - Common work results for fire protection.pdf
Observation/Comments: Requirement for dry-type sprinkler systems in areas exposed to freezing does not define what areas are considered subject to freezing; need coordination with architectural/mechanical drawings to identify these spaces.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 210500 - Common work results for fire protection.pdf
Observation/Comments: Shop drawing requirement calls for “balanced supply and demand for the appropriate hazard class as defined in NFPA 13” but does not identify hazard classifications by space type; request schedule or criteria to avoid assumptions during hydraulic design.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 210500 - Common work results for fire protection.pdf
Observation/Comments: Related work list references firestopping, flashing, and sealants but does not clearly assign responsibility for fire-rated FP penetrations and coordination with Division 07; clarify which trade provides and installs firestopping at FP sleeves.

Spec lists firestops for various penetration types but does not reference required tested systems (UL, FM, or other listings); need clarification that all penetrations for FP piping will use listed assemblies matching each wall/floor rating.

Penetrations at each floor level in shafts/stairwells are included, but no explicit coordination note with standpipes, sprinkler risers, or stair pressurization ductwork; request confirmation that FP penetrations in shafts will be detailed and sealed to maintain required shaft ratings and pressurization integrity.

Related sections reference piping, duct, cable, and conduit penetrations but do not clearly assign responsibility for firestopping around FP piping vs. other trades; clarify which trade provides and installs firestopping at sprinkler/standpipe penetrations to avoid scope gaps.

Fire alarm spec lists sprinkler and standpipe alarm/supervisory devices and interfaces with pre-action/clean agent systems, but does not reference coordination with sprinkler/standpipe shop drawings or NFPA 13/14 requirements; clarify FP integration responsibilities.

Smoke control and post-fire smoke purge panels are included, but no reference is made to coordination with mechanical smoke control design and stair/shaft pressurization sequences; request coordination requirements and applicable NFPA/IBC sections.

Section references “area of rescue assistance” intercom stations and magnetic door holders but does not state door release logic or interface requirements with fire/smoke doors and egress components; clarify cause-and-effect matrix and code basis.
No performance criteria stated for audibility/intelligibility of notification appliances (e.g., dBA levels, voice intelligibility per NFPA 72); request inclusion to avoid field disputes.

Interfaces with pre-action/clean agent systems are mentioned generically without specifying which systems or sequence of operations (pre-action trip, agent release, shutdowns); request detailed interface description and responsibility matrix.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 266008.01 - Emergency responder auxiliary bi-directional radio communication system.pdf
Observation/Comments: Summary text contains placeholder “<insert other agency if required>,” indicating emergency responder users and coverage requirements are not finalized; request confirmation of all AHJ agencies and their radio requirements before design.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 266008.01 - Emergency responder auxiliary bi-directional radio communication system.pdf
Observation/Comments: Section does not clearly state minimum in-building radio signal strength, coverage percentages, or testing criteria per NFPA 72/1221/1225 and local code; request explicit performance metrics to size BDA system.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 266008.01 - Emergency responder auxiliary bi-directional radio communication system.pdf
Observation/Comments: Baseline radio signal strength testing is required but timing relative to building construction (core/shell vs. fit-out) and responsible party are not defined; clarify schedule and contractor responsibility to avoid delays.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 266008.01 - Emergency responder auxiliary bi-directional radio communication system.pdf
Observation/Comments: Specification allows systems to be “combined only as allowed by the agencies,” but does not state if separate BDAs are required for fire vs. police or if shared systems are acceptable; request AHJ guidance to avoid redesign.

Generator spec lists “outdoor enclosure” and fuel system but does not address fire protection requirements for fuel storage, fire rating of enclosure/room, or integration with fire alarm (run status, trouble, emergency stop); request coordination with FP and code requirements.

Transfer switch spec references a separate section for electric-drive fire pumps but does not clearly state that fire pump transfer switches must be dedicated and comply with NFPA 20 (no other loads, bypass features, location); request explicit fire pump ATS requirements.

Single-line diagram requirements do not explicitly require showing fire pump, fire alarm, and life safety loads separately from non–life safety loads; request clarification to ensure emergency power system complies with NFPA 70/110 and FP priorities.

Section covers molded-case circuit breakers and enclosures but does not identify any fire pump or fire alarm service disconnect requirements (e.g., locked-on, supervision, location); request clarification for devices serving FP systems.

Seismic performance is referenced generally to ASCE/SEI 7, but there is no cross-reference to NFPA 13/72 seismic bracing and operational requirements for FP-related power equipment; request coordination language so FP systems remain operational after seismic events.

Fire hydrant locations and FDC are shown but no dimensions to building entrances or fire lanes; ability for fire department access and hose reach, especially during potential flood events noted in general notes, is not clearly documented.

Underground fire service, hydrant, and FDC piping are indicated as “by others” with no clear responsibility for coordination with building FP risers and backflow location; potential constructability/ownership gap.

Flow test data provided but no explicit indication of required sprinkler system design criteria (hazard classification, density/area, hose allowance) tied to this test, making adequacy of water supply for intended FP systems unclear.
FDC symbol shown but piping routing to building riser/backflow not clearly indicated; connection, size, and check valve/backflow arrangement are ambiguous for construction.

General notes reference NFPA standards but do not clearly address interface of site FP work with flood protection or elevation of critical components (FDC, backflow) above flood levels, which may affect constructability and code compliance.

No seismic bracing layout or notes for FP piping on this level despite project seismic requirements referenced elsewhere; constructability and compliance with NFPA 13 seismic provisions are not documented.

Building height and listed pressures suggest very high static pressures at lower high-zone floors; no indication of intermediate pressure zones or relief valves to prevent overpressure in sprinkler systems tied to standpipes.

Interface between high-zone schematic and high-zone fire pump drawings (FP-30/FP-31) is not clearly labeled with pipe IDs and valve references; potential for misconnection between Tower 1 and Tower 2 high-zone risers.
Hose valve symbols by floor are not coordinated with architectural stair plans; no confirmation that valves are on intermediate landings and located within required distance from stairs/doors.
No seismic design notes or requirements provided for standpipe risers in high zone; seismic bracing and flexible connections at building joints are not addressed.
Flow test data or design basis (city main pressure, required demand) driving pump sizing and PRV settings is not shown on schematic; ability to verify overall system hydraulic adequacy is limited.
No fire riser/standpipe routing, vertical main locations, or floor control valve assemblies indicated in this section; unclear how FP piping serves each level.
Stair and shaft areas not shown with standpipe riser locations or hose valve elevations; compliance with NFPA 14 not verifiable.
No indication of fire pump room location, fire service entrance, or backflow location relative to grade; vertical FP system integration with building not documented.
Sprinkler coverage, clear heights, and coordination with beams/soffits in garage and podium levels not shown in section; potential for hidden obstructions.
Seismic bracing details for FP piping not clearly indicated; unclear if system meets NFPA 13 seismic requirements for this risk category.
Details show generic pendent/sidewall arrangements but do not address coordination with specific ceiling types, soffits, or cloud ceilings used in project; risk of conflicts with architectural RCPs.
Flex-head detail provided without maximum length and number of bends limitations; NFPA 13 compliance for equivalent length and friction loss not verifiable.
No explicit detail for FP pipe penetrations through rated walls/floors and required UL assemblies; firestopping responsibilities and methods are ambiguous.
Notes reference design criteria but no specific required density/area, hazard classifications by space type, or water supply test data; contractor design basis is unclear.
Location and discharge routing for inspector’s test and main drains not coordinated with architectural/site (no indication of where drains terminate).

Abbreviation note references “type and rating system” but does not clearly define rating criteria or minimum ratings per occupancy; contractor cannot verify code-compliant ratings.
Mounting bracket spec is generic and does not define mounting heights or ADA reach requirements; risk of noncompliant installation.

Electrical legend and notes do not clearly identify power requirements, normal/emergency feeds, or coordination notes for fire pump, jockey pump, or fire alarm control equipment; FP–electrical interface is not defined.

Section states inclusion of meters and gauges but does not define which FP systems (sprinkler risers, fire pump test headers, standpipes, tank levels) require which instruments; layout and coordination with riser/floor control assemblies are unclear.

Submittal requirements reference schedules of locations but no basis or standard (e.g., NFPA 13/20 required gauge locations) is cited; risk of missing gauges at key points like fire pump suction/discharge and system risers.
Products are introduced but no minimum pressure ratings, accuracy classes, or connection sizes are stated; may lead to incompatible or undersized gauges/meters for system pressures.

Reference Drawing(s)/Location: 230517 - Sleeves and sleeve seals for hvac piping.pdf
Observation/Comments: Sleeves and sleeve seals are specified for HVAC piping only; there is no indication that fire sprinkler/standpipe piping penetrations are to follow this section or a separate FP section, creating ambiguity for FP sleeve and seal requirements at walls/floors, including rated assemblies.

Escutcheon requirements are written for HVAC piping penetrations, but do not clearly state applicability to fire sprinkler/standpipe piping, leading to uncertainty on FP escutcheon type and finish, especially at rated walls/ceilings.

Electrical common work section requires scale drawings indicating insert and sleeve locations and coordination drawings for access panels/doors, but there is no explicit requirement to coordinate these with fire protection mains, risers, and sprinkler access needs, risking conflicts and inaccessible FP valves or devices.
Coordination between sprinkler mains/branches and large mechanical ductwork/shafts is not shown; potential conflicts and obstructions to sprinkler discharge need resolution.
Sprinkler head types (e.g., ordinary vs. intermediate temperature, upright vs. pendent) in mechanical rooms are not called out; confirm head selection for high-heat or obstructed areas.
Relationship between stair pressurization ductwork and standpipe/sprinkler piping in stairs is not detailed; need coordination to avoid clearance and access conflicts.

Structural cover sheet shows extensive transfer slabs and outriggers but provides no FP coordination notes for penetrations, sleeves, or fire-rated shaft locations; early coordination of main risers and standpipes with structure is not addressed.

General summary does not clearly state that FP subcontractor is responsible for coordinating penetrations and firestopping of rated assemblies; request clarification of FP scope for rated wall/floor penetrations.

Standpipe specification only identifies “Automatic Wet-Type, Class I Standpipe System” with NPS 2-1/2 hose connections; no criteria given for additional Class II/III hose outlets, combined sprinkler/standpipe risers, or zoning, making coordination with sprinkler systems and architectural layouts unclear.

Standpipe spec references wet and dry sprinkler sections but does not clearly define required hydraulic design basis (NFPA 14 class, demand point, or remote hose valve assumptions), which can cause inconsistencies with sprinkler hydraulic calculations and fire pump sizing.

Wet system spec requires “building or area will be fully sprinklered (exception only as per local code)” but does not define any unprotected or limited-coverage spaces (elevator shafts, small closets, canopies, parking, etc.), creating ambiguity for sprinkler coverage and potential gaps in shop drawing scope.

Specification requires hydraulic calculations per NFPA 13 but does not state design density/area criteria by hazard or by occupancy (light/ordinary/extra), leaving sizing of mains, risers, and fire pump demand ambiguous for bidding and coordination.

Text states “all areas will be supplied from a combination, standpipe, or sprinkler riser system” without defining which areas are on combination risers versus dedicated sprinkler risers, making standpipe/sprinkler riser coordination and valve arrangement unclear.

Areas exposed to freezing are directed to have dry pipe systems but there is no cross-reference to specific locations or architectural envelopes; unclear which zones must be dry and how transitions to wet systems and standpipes are to be arranged.

Fire pump spec lists components (pumps, controllers, transfer switches, etc.) but does not state required pump capacity, net pressure, or redundancy (duty/jockey/backup), leaving major sizing assumptions for standpipe and sprinkler systems undefined.

Performance requirements reference a “Schedule” for pressure ratings and motor size but that schedule is not included on this page; without explicit values, coordination of fire pump, pipe ratings, and overpressure protection is ambiguous.

Shop drawing requirements call for plans, elevations, and clearances but do not state minimum working clearances around the pump, controller, and test header per NFPA 20, which may result in an undersized fire pump room on architectural drawings.

Fire-resistive material spec references firestops and smokeseals but does not address protection/repair of rated assemblies at penetrations by fire protection piping (sprinkler mains, standpipes), leaving coordination of UL assemblies and through-penetration firestopping for FP systems unclear.

Requirement to identify restrained/unrestrained assemblies and thicknesses on shop drawings does not explicitly require coordination with sprinkler hanger and seismic brace attachments, risking field conflicts where FP supports disturb fireproofing thickness or rating.

Intumescent fireproofing is specified for “fireproofed steel exposed view” but there is no direction on coordinating with sprinkler head locations, piping supports, or hangers that may penetrate or be adjacent to coated steel, creating risk of coating damage and rating compromise.

Related sections list structural steel and painting but omit explicit coordination with Division 21 fire protection piping/penetrations, leaving unclear how intumescent coatings at beam/column locations will be protected where sprinkler hangers and standpipe supports are attached.

Life safety legends focus on egress and ratings; there is no explicit cross-reference to FP drawings for sprinkler/standpipe criteria (design density, hazard classification, garage vs. residential vs. mechanical), creating ambiguity in FP design basis for these levels.

Life safety plans do not show fire hose cabinet locations, fire extinguisher locations, or any coordination notes with FP drawings; first-responder equipment placement and coordination with architectural finishes are unclear.

Life safety sheets include egress and rating data but no cross-reference to FP drawings, sprinkler design criteria (NFPA edition, hazard classification, design area), or fire pump/standpipe basis; overall FP code strategy on upper levels is ambiguous.
